News.Heading: 8 members of Dujana gang held, 6 SUVs, illegal arms seized
News.text: GREATER NOIDA: Police on Thursday night arrested eight members of Dujana gang when the police team was conducting flag march in preparedness of upcoming panchayat elections in Dujana village. The gang members started pelting stones at the police personnel and damaged the police vehicles. The police seized six SUVs and several illegal weapons from their possession. The accused have been identified as Naresh, Virendra, Anil, Madan, Titu Nagar, Ravinder, Om Prakash and Chatru. Om Prakash is brother and Chatru is father of dreaded criminal Anil Dujana, who is presently in Banda district jail in connection with several criminal cases. Anil Dujana, Chatru and Om Prakash's wife have filed nomination papers for the upcoming panchayat elections. The gang members were also threatening rival candidates to withdraw nomination papers or face dire consequences. Abhishek Yadav, SP (rural) Gautam Budh Nagar, said that the police team was conducting a flag march in sensitive areas in the preparedness of the panchayat polls. "The police team was crossing on road near Anil Dujana's house in the evening. We found a number of vehicles parked outside his house. The gang members started creating ruckus and protesting against the police march. They started pelting stones and damaged the police vehicles," Yadav said. Two police constables received minor injuries in the incident. The police team raided the premises and arrested the criminals. A case has been registered against the accused persons under Sections 147, 148, 341, 332, 353, 427, 34 of IPC in Badalpur police station.
News.Heading: Haryanvi film on female foeticide might soon be screened all across Gurgaon
News.text: Last Sunday, the Municipal Corporation of Gurgaon (MCG) screened a Haryanvi feature film about female foeticide, which was released in 2011. Now, the MCG plans to screen the film, 'Aathwan Vachan - Ek Pratigya', in every ward of Gurgaon. "We will speak to the deputy commissioner, TL Satyaprakash (who is also the MCG chief), about screening it in different parts of Gurgaon. The issue addressed in the film is in sync with the central government's Save The Girl Child campaign," says SS Rohilla, PRO, MCG. Ramniwas Sharma, a Gurgaon-based businessman who produced the film, said that thanks to the Beti Bachao Beti Padhao scheme, his film is now getting the support that he sought five years back. Talking about what inspired him to make a film, Sharma says, "About 35 years ago, prenatal sex determination was not a crime. Sarkari hospitals mein bhi hota tha, kyunki yeh population kam karne ka ek maadhyam bhi tha. My father was a priest and poet. He was against it and so he introduced the aathwan vachan (the eighth vow) in the Hindu wedding ritual - vowing not to kill the girl child." Sharma adds, "When people refused to take the vow, he would simply not conduct the ceremony and leave. He also wrote many poems on the issue." The film, made on a budget of Rs35 lakhs, stars actors from the National School of Drama and has been directed by Krishna Nahariya. It has seven songs, six of them written by Sharma's father Kaam Singh and one by Sharma himself. The South City 1 resident says that he thought that a film was the best medium to spread awareness. "I narrated one of my father's poems to my neighbours, who are from Bihar. They were deeply moved, despite not understanding Haryanvi, simply because pain is a universal language. Also, I thought ki agar films criminals ko inspire kar sakti hain (by giving them ideas for crimes), toh baki logon ko kyun nahin," he says. In 1980, Sharma, inspired by Dharmendra, had gone to Mumbai to work in Bollywood, but couldn't find any roles. "Three decades later, after having earned enough money, I again went to Mumbai to give work to Mumbai-based artistes. They again disappointed me. They found no sense in making an issue-oriented film, and asked me to invest in a love story," he adds. Sharma, however, soon found the cast and crew for his film in NCR, and it was released in five districts in Haryana. "My motive was not to earn money, but to send across my father's message. I wanted the state government to promote it, but all they could do was make it tax-free." Sharing another anecdote, Sharma says, "In 2012, a conference for child specialists took place in Gurgaon. Someone told them about my film and they contacted me for a screening. But since most of the doctors didn't know Haryanvi, a team of doctors worked on English subtitles for the film, including the correct medical terms. And the film became one of the few Haryanvi films with English subtitles." Sharma likes to believe that his film might have inspired the current government's Save The Girl Child campaign. "I had shown the film to Somabhai Modi, Narendra Modi's elder brother, during an event. He asked me for a CD, and said that he would show it to the PM. As we all know, the PM launched the Beti Bachao Beti Padhao campaign from Panipat. At the launch of the campaign, artistes sang a song from the film - 'Maa Tu Mane Marvaiye Na'. The song was also made the callertune of all the Haryana government officials who are part of the campaign," says Sharma, who has named his newborn granddaughter NaMo. "The old lady who plays the antagonist in the film has a change of heart at the end of the film. She then travels all across Haryana asking people to take the eighth vow. Similarly, I screen the film wherever I can, and ask people to take the vow," says Sharma.
News.Heading: Indian-American teen wins Intel Young Scientist Award
News.text: WASHINGTON: A 15-year-old Indian-American boy has won the prestigious 'Intel Foundation Young Scientist Award' for developing a low-cost electronically-aided knee brace that allows a person with a weakened leg to walk more naturally. Syamantak Payra, a Texas resident, won the $50,000 award along with 17-year-old Kathy Liu. The award was given by Intel Corporation and the Society for Science and the Public (SSP) at the 2016 'Intel International Science and Engineering Fair' in Arizona last week. "Our top winners this year, Syamantak and Kathy, clearly demonstrate that age has no bearing on your ability to conduct research and come up with solutions to important problems," said Maya Ajmera, SSP president and chief executive. "We congratulate them not only for their success, but on their dedication and hard work. They and the rest of the Intel International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF) finalists are the rising stars of STEM and we look forward to watching them pursue their passions and in turn make the world a better place for future generations," Ajmera said. When Payra tested his prototype with two individuals partially disabled by polio, it almost immediately restored a more natural gait and increased mobility, according to a statement. "Intel congratulates this year's winners and hopes that their work will inspire other young innovators to apply their curiosity and ingenuity to today's global challenges," Intel Foundation president and Intel Corporation vice president of human resources and director of corporate affairs Rosalind Hudnell said in a statement. 2017's Intel ISEF featured more than 1,700 young scientists selected from 419 affiliate fairs held in 77 countries. A team of students from India also attended the event. Five Indian Americans also figured in the 22 "Best of Category" winners and each received a $5,000 prize. These winners included Rajeev Jha (Hawaii) in the Behavioral and Social Sciences category, Marissa Sumathipala (Virginia) in the Cellular and Molecular Biology, Swetha Revanur (California) in Computational Biology and Bioinformatics, Tiasha Joardar (Texas) in the Energy: Physical category and Prashant Godishala (Minnesota) in the Translational Medical Science. Under the Intel and Indo-US Science & Technology Forum, three students won the award for a visit to India.
News.Heading: Indian wins award at UN's poster contest on nuclear disarmament
News.text: UNITED NATIONS: A 22-year-old Indian artist is among the three winners of a UN poster competition aimed at raising awareness about nuclear disarmament, with her poster of a peace dove slicing through a nuclear weapon garnering appreciation from UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon. Anjali Chandrashekar, a New York-based designer and "artivist", won the third prize in UN Poster for Peace contest presented by the UN Office for Disarmament Affairs (ODA) to raise awareness of the need for nuclear disarmament. Titled 'Cutting Barriers through Peace', the poster features a peace dove slicing through a nuclear weapon. (Image: Facebook/art.anjali) She received her third-prize certificate from Ban at an award ceremony held here on May 3. Apart from the three winners, nine honorable mentions were chosen from among more than 4,100 entries representing 123 countries. The young artist was only 10 when she founded 'Picture It', a non-governmental organisation that uses imagery to raise awareness and funds for various health, humanitarian and environmental causes. Another poster 'Break Free' by the Chennai girl, that shows doves flying out of a bird cage at the top of a nuclear weapon, received an honorable mention. "Nuclear disarmament is usually spoken about on such a high level and I believe that art has the power to humanize some of the most pressing issues that the world faces today," she told the UN News Centre. "It also transcends barriers of age, language and literacy so I thought this was a great opportunity for me to show that a brush can be mightier than arms." The first prize went to 38-year-old Ivan Ciro Palomino Huamani from Peru for his 'Spinning Peace', which features a nuclear weapon being unraveled into string which is then used to fly kites and balloons, and to jump rope. Second place winner, 15-year-old Michelle Li, named her poster 'Peace in our Hands', which features a shadow puppet of a peace dove above a broken nuclear weapon. Congratulating the winners, Ban said he commends them for the "talents you have displayed, and for using those talents to highlight such an essential cause." "At a time of many global needs, it is important that young people are aware of the threat posed by nuclear weapons, and the vital importance of disarmament. Young people did not create nuclear weapons, but it may be their task to eliminate them once and for all. The energy and enthusiasm, talent and new ideas we see here today will help to meet that challenge," he said at the award ceremony. Actor Michael Douglas , a UN Messenger of Peace, said that "creativity is essential" to creating momentum for nuclear disarmament. The competition was organised to commemorate the anniversary of the very first UN General Assembly resolution adopted in 1946 establishing a Commission to deal with problems related to the discovery of atomic energy.
News.Heading: Indian-origin appointed dean at Calgary University in Canada
News.text: TORONTO: An Indian-origin veterinary medical expert has been appointed as the Dean of the prestigious University of Calgary's Faculty of Veterinary Medicine in Canada. Baljit Singh, will take over the position of Dean on September 1, provost and vice-president (Academic) of the university Dru Marshall said in a statement. Singh is a highly accomplished researcher, educator and administrator in the field of veterinary medicine, with specific expertise in lung biology and anatomy, she said. Singh has done his Bachelor of Veterinary Science and Animal Husbandry and Master of Veterinary Science from Punjab Agricultural University. He completed his PhD from the University of Guelph in Ontario and postdoctoral training at Texas A and M University and Columbia University, New York. "I am deeply honored to be selected as the dean of the University of Calgary's Faculty of Veterinary Medicine. I am excited that the faculty has outstanding opportunities to lead in veterinary medical education and knowledge-creation to solve complex animal and human problems at the local, national and international level," Singh said in a statement issues by the university.
News.Heading: 1,700 Indian workers arrested, deported from Kuwait says government
News.text: NEW DELHI: About 1,700 Indian workers who were arrested and deported by Kuwaiti authorities were found violating visa or residency laws of that country, government said today. "There is no problem in the case of people who have valid work visa as their problems are solved under the agreements (with foreign countries)," Minister of State for External Affairs V K Singh said during Question Hour in Rajya Sabha. However, the task becomes difficult when workers reach foreign countries on tourist visas and then get them converted to work visas "through dubious means", he said. It is also not possible to keep records of all such people but added that the government reaches out to assist all its citizens promptly if they are found to be in a problem in a foreign land, Singh said. He said the government was sensitive to the needs of its workers and has "effective" agreements with many Gulf countries including Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and Bahrain to ensure their safety. The minister said the government has already set up an Indian Workers Resource Centre in Dubai and will set up two more in Saudi Arabia and Malaysia. Singh said he and his senior Minister Sushma Swaraj actively check their twitter accounts to reach out to any person needing assistance, while missions abroad were also sensitive to problems faced by any citizen. He said with the Ministry of Overseas Indian Affairs now merged with MEA, there was more coordinated effort in this regard.
News.Heading: Indian worker dies at Qatar World Cup stadium site
News.text: DOHA: An Indian worker died at the construction site of the Al-Bayt 2022 World Cup Stadium after he fell ill, the tournament's Organising Committee announced on Sunday. The worker, 48, died on Wednesday after suffering a cardiac arrest at the stadium's construction site in the Qatari city of al-Khor. Qatar's Supreme Committee for Delivery and Legacy of the 2022 World Cup announced that it has opened an investigation into the death of the Indian labourer to determine the circumstances of the incident. The conditions of workers building the Qatar World Cup stadiums have been reported to be very poor by several human rights organisations. Report of the deaths of hundreds of workers have also emerged. In March, Amnesty International warned against labour exploitation of immigrants in the construction work of the 2022 World Cup stadiums and facilities, and said that workers were living in subhuman conditions, without even the most basic of rights.
News.Heading: Canada Pastures - A farm-to-fork carrot success tale
News.text: Sahota brothers, who emigrated to Canada from the Doaba region of Punjab where every other homestead has an NRI, are today the largest producers of carrots in western Canada. In fact, a packet of carrots, potatoes, cabbage or parsnips at any supermarket in Canada invariably bears the label of Sahotas' Canadian Farms. "Though we produce many crops such as potatoes, cabbage, parsnips, pumpkins and others, we are the largest carrot growers in western Canada. And we are the only producer of baby carrots in the whole of western Canada," says Amrik Sahota, the youngest of the four Sahota brothers who hail from Phalpota village, near Jalandhar, in Punjab. The four Sikh brothers Avtar Sahota, Sucha Sahota, Ranbir Sahota and Amrik Sahota have revolutionized carrot cultivation in Canada. "Our farming operations spread over 900 acres yield the best carrots in Canada. Last year, we produced over 10,0000 tons of carrot and shipped it across Canada, the US and elsewhere. Though the US and Canada are our main markets, we also ship to Dubai and Thailand," says Amrik. In less than three decades, the four hard-working Punjabi brothers have become the top carrot producers by employing state-of-the-art technology. Their sales turnover topped $15 million last year. "We have procured the best technology from around the world to stay ahead of the competition. We have imported costly machines from Germany, Denmark, Holland, the US and Belgium. All our farming from sowing to harvesting are tech-oriented," explains the youngest of the Sahota brothers. Though they employ hundreds of people during their peak season from June to December, Canadian Farms are essentially a state-of-the-art farming operation where just three persons manning one machine can harvest up to 18 tons of crop in 45 minutes! The Sahotas are a typical Punjabi immigrant success story in Canada. Their eldest brother landed as an immigrant in Vancouver in 1970 and then the whole family joined him in 1976. And just like any new immigrant, they worked in factories to make a living in their earlier years. "But farming was in our DNA. So we bought 40 acres in Cloverdale near Vancouver even when we used to work in factories. It was only in 1988 that we decided to make a living out of it," says Amrik. The Sahota brothers started off farming operations with cabbage and lettuces. In 1992, as they just incorporated their operations under the brand name of Canadian Farms, they got lucky when they got a quota to supply carrot to major store chains. As Amrik explains, "Unlike Punjab, we have an organized and regulated marketing system here for farm produce. When we got a quota to supply carrot, it is then when we took its cultivation seriously."
News.Heading: In-laws booked for harassing NRI woman for dowry
News.text: PHAGWARA: Police on Friday booked the husband, father-in-law and mother-in-law of an NRI woman, for allegedly harassing her for more dowry and forcing her to marry another relative. Police booked Komalpreet Kaur's husband Parvinder Singh, father-in-law Balbir Singh and mother-in-law Balbir Kaur under various sections of IPC. Police said that Baljinder, who lives in the US, had married off his daughter to Parvinder from Nangal Majha village on February 20, 2013. He spent Rs 20 lakh on the marriage and also gave the family expensive gifts. But his daughter's in-laws started demanding a luxury car. They also started insisting that Komalpreet divorce her husband and marry another person from their family so he could also go to the US. When Komalpreet refused, they told her that they had married her to their son so that another relative could travel to the US after their son divorced her. The in-laws forced her to leave her marital home. Upon returning home to her parents, Komalpreet lodged a complaint with the police.
News.Heading: Indian American scientist Rakesh K Jain to get medal of science from Barack Obama
News.text: WASHINGTON: A 65-year-old Indian American scientist is set to receive the prestigious 'National Medal of Science' award from US President Barack Obama. Rakesh K Jain, a professor of tumour biology at Massachusetts General Hospital in the Harvard Medical School, will receive the award from Obama along with 16 other recipients of the 'National Medals of Science and National Medals of Technology and Innovation' on May 19. The award function was initially scheduled for January 22 but was postponed due to a major snow storm, the White House said yesterday. Awarded annually, the Medal of Science recognises individuals who have made outstanding contributions to science, engineering and mathematics. The National Medal of Technology and Innovation recognises those who have made lasting contributions to America's competitiveness and quality of life and helped strengthen nation's technological workforce. Jain, an IIT-Kanpur alumnus, has received numerous awards for his work on tumour biology, particularly research on the link between tumour blood vessels and improving the effects of chemotherapy and radiation treatment. He received his B Tech degree from the IIT-Kanpur in Chemical Engineering in 1972. The National Medal of Science was created by statute in 1959 and is administered for the White House by the National Science Foundation.
News.Heading: Indian-origin entrepreneur launches new global education fund
News.text: DUBAI: An Indian-origin entrepreneur in the UAE on Sunday launched a new $200,000 fund to support education projects around the world by providing good teachers and quality education to every child including refugees. Kerala-born Sunny Varkey, 59, a Dubai-based education philanthropist, launched the Varkey Foundation Challenge Fund here at the two-day Global Education and Skills Forum 2016. The first allocations of the fund will go for projects in the Middle East, China, Ghana and Ukraine, Varkey said. "The Challenge Fund looks to support early-stage initiatives which build the capacity of teachers and to strengthen the status of the teaching profession. As with the Global Teacher Prize, it is part of the Varkey Foundation's vision of providing every child with a good teacher and a quality education," Varkey said.
News.Heading: GMR to invest Rs 471 crore to set up LNG terminal on east coast
News.text: HYDERABAD: GMR Group is in the process of setting up an LNG (liquefied natural gas) terminal at Andhra Pradesh's Kakinada sea port with an investment of Rs 471 crore. According to minutes of the meeting held by Expert Appraisal Committee (EAC) under the Ministry of Environment and Forests, the project envisages a start-up capacity of 1.75 million tonnes per annum (MTPA) which comprises of captive use by GMR Energy Limited to the tune of 0.85 MTPA, with the balance for domestic piped and non-piped users within a radius of 450km. "GMR Holding Pvt Ltd has proposed for development of LNG facility with capacity of 1.75 MTPA at Kakinada Deep Water Port (KDWP) berth 7 located adjacent to survey no. 317/318, GMR barge mounted power plant located at survey no. 411, 413, tehsil Kakinada, district East Godavari, Andhra Pradesh. "The proposed LNG facility consists of the following ... development of necessary facility/ equipment for ship berthing and mooring, LNG unloading arms with all safety measures, LNG storage and transportation, onshore insulated cryogenic pipeline, LNG regasification facility and pipeline for connectivity to existing gas distribution grid," the EAC said. While recommending the term of reference for the project, the EAC asked the company to conduct a public hearing, besides laying down other conditions. "During presentation, project proponent (GMR) informed that regasification plant will also be installed at berth no 7. Cost of project is Rs 471 crore. Power requirement will be 8MW. Coringa Wildlife Sanctuary is located at a distance of 1.5km south," it said. Meanwhile, the EAC deferred its decision on environmental and CRZ clearance in case of proposed greenfield facility for import of 5 MMTPA LNG Floating Storage Unit (FSU) and handling facility within Krishnapatnam Port Ltd, Nellore, Andhra Pradesh by LNG Bharat Pvt Ltd. The committee suggested the project proponent that it should submit all the requisite documents to Andhra Pradesh Coastal Zone Management Authority as sought by them.
News.Heading: 6 tasks for new financial year
News.text: Investors and taxpayers should complete some tasks this month itself. The madness of March may be over, but if you take up the following tasks in April itself, it can save you headaches later in the year. Start tax planning right away Experts say it is best to start tax planning at the beginning of the financial year. If you plan to invest in ELSS, it is best to start an SIP in April itself. Our research shows that investors who took the SIP route earned more than those who waited till March to invest in ELSS schemes.Staggering the investments across 12 months not only cushions you against volatility, but also lighten the burden at the end of the financial year. TIME REQUIRED: 2-3 HOURS Get papers ready for tax filing The tax filing deadline is three months away, but it will help if you start putting together the information needed for filing returns. If you have foreign assets or earned foreign income during the year, start collecting documents right away. The tax department will be scrutinizing your interest income. Banks credit the interest on the balance in savings bank accounts in October and April. Add the total interest across bank accounts. Also add interest you would have earned on infrastructure bonds, NSCs, fixed and recurring deposits and other fixed income securities. If you have a home loan or an education loan running, get a certificate of interest to know the deduction you can claim. TIME REQUIRED: 2-3 HOURS Increase quantum of investments Your next paycheque could be fatter. You need to increase investments proportionately. Contribution to the EPF automatically. You can also increase the existing SIP amount or start fresh SIPs in other funds. TIME REQUIRED: 2-3 HOURS Submit Form 15G and 15H to avoid TDS This is also the time to file Form 15G or 15H to avoid TDS on interest. Form 15G can be filed by investors below 60 who do not have any tax liability and whose total income from interest is below `2.5 lakh. Form 15H is for individuals above 60. It can be filed if the final tax on the investor's estimated total income is nil.So, if you are above 60, your taxable income can be up to `3 lakh for you to be eligible for 15H. For super senior citizens above 80 years, this limit is `5 lakh. TIME REQUIRED: 1-2 HOURS Give VPF mandate to employer Instead of the PPF which will give 8.1%, salaried individuals can consider the Voluntary Provident Fund (VPF). VPF contributions are eligible for tax deduction under Sec 80C and are tax-free on withdrawal. Even if EPF becomes taxable in later years, the existing corpus will not get taxed. Submit your VPF mandate to the employer immediately. TIME REQUIRED: 15-20 MINUTES Organise investment portfolio If you don't know your asset allocation because all investments are not at one place, start using a portfolio tracker. Value Research has made it simpler for its users. All they have to do is upload the consolidated mutual fund statement and NPS details and all transactions get incorporated into the portfolio. TIME REQUIRED: 1-2 HOURS
News.Heading: Sensex slides 58 pts as IT continues to be a drag
News.text: MUMBAI: Shrugging off strong macroeconomic data, the benchmark BSE Sensex fell for the second straight session today and settled nearly 58 points down at 26.846.53 as IT stocks continued slide on caution ahead of TCS results. A weak trend in global markets after a data showed slump in Chinese imports, fuelling worries about the health of Asia's largest economy also weighed on the sentiments. Software stocks remained under pressure for the second straight day after Infosys yesterday slashed its dollar revenue guidance, clouding the outlook for the overall sector. The 30-share BSE Sensex after shuttling between 26,918.52 and 26,719.10 during the session finally settled lower by 57.58 points or 0.21 per cent at 26,846.53. The 50-share Nifty too dropped 11.90 points or 0.15 per cent to end at 8,131.70 after dipping below the crucial 8,100 level to hit a low of 8,088.60. The market showed some signs of firmness in early trade on the back of positive macroeconomic data with industrial production grew at a nearly three-year high of 6.4 per cent in August. However, retail inflation rising to 4.41 per cent in September, had a negative impact, and triggered selling. "Indices are struggling to maintain their crucial levels as selling emerges at every rise," said Manoj Choraria, a Delhi-based NSE broker. A cautious stance from the participants trimming positions ahead of the TCS earnings announcement, later in the day, too influenced trading sentiment. Stocks of TCS, country's largest software company, managed to close in the green at Rs 2,597.40 with mild gains. Sensex losers included ONGC, Hindalco, Vedanta, Tata Steel, Infosys, Bharti Airtel, GAIL, Sun Pharma, L&T, Hero MotoCorp, SBI, Tata Motors, HDFC Bank and HUL. Bucking the trend, Coal India, Lupin, BHEL, Bajaj Auto, Maruti Suzuki, ITC, Dr Reddy's, Axis Bank, M&M, HDFC, Cipla, NTPC and RIL notched up gains up to 1.79 per cent. Of the 30-share pack, 15 closed with losses. Sector-wise, IT suffered the most by falling 1.03 per cent, followed by teck with a drop of 0.87 per cent. Broader markets, however, were in better shape as investors made selective buying, with the BSE small-cap rising 0.41 per cent while mid-cap index gained 0.02 per cent. Globally, other Asian markets ended lower with Japan's Nikkei and Hong Kong's Hang Seng falling up to 1.11 per cent, while European markets were showing an easy trend in their opening deals.
News.Heading: Special drive by railway police to enforce alcohol prohibition
News.text: BHAGALPUR: Train passengers beware! Carrying liquor, travelling after consuming liquor or clandestinely consuming liquor in the running trains would land them in big trouble including jail as the railway passengers have been put under the railway police's scanner. The railway police, on the basis of reports about smuggling of liquor through trains originating from Jharkhand, West Bengal, Assam, Maharashtra, Delhi etc and passing through the state besides consuming liquor kept in cold water bottles being carried by them, have undertaken painstaking initiative to stop the menace. In the special drive undertaken by the government railway police (GRP) between the Kiul-Jamalpur-Bhagalpur-Sahebganj railway section, the police teams of GRP has embarked on drive to check the train passengers and their luggage to stop liquor peddling in the region. Apart from checking the baggage, the GRP is being equipped with 'breathe analyzers' in order to examine the suspected passengers and take legal action against the offenders for having consumed alcohol or consuming alcohol inside the running train, causing nuisance to co-passengers besides violating the new Bihar Excise (Amendment) Act, 2016 that prohibits sale and consumption of country-made alcohol (CML) and Indian Made Foreign Liquors (IMFLs) from April 5, 2016. Passengers apart, the staffs of 'pantry car', from where food (eatables) and beverages (cold drinks, tea etc) are supplied to the passengers of long distance trains, have also been put under GRP scanner in the backdrop of reports about alcohol being secretly supplied to some of the passengers. It may be worth mentioning here that a pantry car staff of 'Vikramshila Express' train was arrested by the GRP and forwarded to jail for carrying bottles of liquor recently. Similarly, three train passengers that included a college student and a bank employee were arrested from Jainagar-Howrah (Dhulian) Express train at Pirpainty station for smuggling several bottles of IMFLs from Sahebganj (Jharkhand) to Bhagalpur (Bihar). The trains that have been shortlisted for special drive to check liquor smuggling and boozing by passengers are Vikramshila Express (Bhagalpur-Delhi-Bhagalpur), Lokmanya Tilak Express (Bhagalpur-Mumbai-Bhagalpur), Sahebganj-Danapur Express, Malda-Jamalpur Express, Surat Express (Bhagalpur-Surat-Bhagalpur), Farakka Express (Farakka-Bhagalpur-Lucknow) New Delhi Weekly (Bhagalpur-Delhi-Bhagalpur), Ajmer Shariff Express (Bhagalpur-Ajmer-Bhagalpur), Vananchal Express (Bhagalpur-Ranchi-Bhagalpur) beside other trains. SP (Railways) Swapna Meshram G., who has taken initiative to undertake special checking drive in the running trains, when contacted by TNN, said that we have geared up the railway machinery to stop violation of new excise law that has completely prohibited sale and consumption of liquor in the state. Boozing in trains is a big offence and hence the railway police with the help of 'breathe analyzers' would check suspected passengers and if found guilty then the passengers would be arrested and sent to jail, added the SP (Railways) saying special drive to check liquor peddling through trains has been started and has resulted in recovery of liquor bottles in huge quantities and arrest of some. Awareness campaign including posters, banners etc about new Bihar Excise (Amendment) Act, 2016, which not only prohibits sale and consumption of liquor, but, also consist of strict provisions of punishments including imprisonment of 10-years to life imprisonment besides penalty of rupees one to ten lakh, are also being undertaken in this railway section, she added.
News.Heading: Prasoon Joshi attends an exhibition on Partition in Delhi
News.text: Documenting memories of Partition Old hand-written letters, black-and-white photographs and objects collected from various sources (including families who lived through the Partition) have been displayed at this exhibition in Delhi. The exhibition, which focuses on refugee camps for displaced people set up on both sides of the border after Partition, is an introduction to the Partition Museum that will be coming up in Amritsar soon. "We have been talking to the Punjab government to decide the venue of the museum in Amritsar. It will tell stories of Partition through various artworks, objects etc. While we are setting up the museum, we will keep doing exhibitions like this one so that people remain engaged. After Amritsar, we also have a plan to bring one such museum to Delhi," said Kishwar Desai , who is leading the project, at the opening of the exhibition. The event was attended by Prasoon Joshi and Ritu Kumar , who are on the advisory committee for the project. Tracing her amritsar roots Ritu told us that she grew up in Amritsar, and the house where she spent her childhood will have a lot of memorabilia that she can contribute to the museum. "We have an old house in Amritsar and now that I am associated with the project, I have to visit it and dig out old pictures and objects. I am sure that I will find many things that should be documented. I have already begun," said the designer. Would love to write more on Partition Prasoon made sure that he attended the opening of the exhibition despite hurting his knee playing badminton. "It is a ligament tear," said Prasoon, who was accompanied by his wife Aparna. "My primary reason for writing 'Bhaag Milkha Bhaag' was that I was moved by what happened during the Partition and how it made someone run so much that he ultimately became a runner. While writing for the film, I researched many stories of Partition," Prasoon added. "I think we should document the memories of Partition so that we can tell future generations about those painful, heart-rending stories. I would want to write more on Partition. A lot more can be done about it in popular culture than what has been done so far. People's expectation from Indian TV is like dal chawal. It is serving comfort food to people. Making something on a subject like Partition will be like throwing a stone in river, something that will create ripples, and I think that should happen," he stressed.
News.Heading: CBSE class 12 results: Visually impaired boy gets 97.4%
News.text: NOIDA: Smiling as he poses for the cameras flashing at him, the confidence of this 18-year old makes one believe that there can never be a problem! For, it is the moment of Rakshit Malik who has scored 97.4 % in the CBSE Board exam results declared on Saturday. The boy with almost 90 % of visual impairment calmly answers when asked about what is difficult or different regarding his study process. Rakshit has bagged the third rank in the differently-abled category of CBSE results and has also shared the first position in his school, Amity, Sector 44 Noida with Unnati Agarwal. A Humanities student, Rakshit says that the impairment caused more problems with growing age but it never affected his zeal for studies, thanks to his parents and his brother. "I never took any coaching classes. If it were my teachers who would read out my lessons for me during extra hours in school, I had my mother at home who would sit with me and ensure that I don't have a problem", Rakshit told TOI. Till he was in fifth standard, he used to write his exams himself but it was when he reached sixth that his vision started getting blurred. "It was then, that my parents arranged a scribe for me. My brother also has a similar problem and he had also availed the services of a scribe," he said. Over-whelmed with her son's achievement, a teary-eyed Rachna Malik explained that according to doctors, it is a genetic disorder that was found in both her children at a very tender age. "My elder son, who has graduated from SRCC, is also visually impaired. But, we never let it become a hindrance. I would sit with him with his notes prepared in enlarged font and read them out to him. Rest is all his toil, Rachna, a resident of Karkardooma in Delhi told TOI. Blessed with impressive oratory and writing skills, Rachit who has scored a 100 in History says he would either become a civil servant or a lecturer. "I would like to join the IFS if possible but I am doubtful about the criteria. Otherwise, I would like to join the academic field as a lecturer." Last year, the Indian Foreign Service had enlisted its first completely blind official, NL Beno Zephine, a 25-year old literature graduate from Chennai.
News.Heading: Anandini: A special girl with a special message for millions of students
News.text: NEW DELHI: A cancer survivor. A student with learning disabilities. An inspiration to thousands of students out there who are thinking of giving up. Meet Anandini Malhotra, the girl who fought all odds and came out with flying colours in her class 12th CBSE board results that were announced today. Anandini was diagnosed with Neuroblastoma, a form of cancer, when she was 2.5-year-old. She had a surgery when she was just three-year-old and later developed a spinal condition called kyfoscoliosis as a fallout of the surgery. In 2014, she had a gruelling 28-hour-long spinal reconstruction surgery that left her in immense pain. "She smiled through it all," recalls her mother who calls Anandini 'her inspiration'. Apart from being a cancer survivor, she is also battling dyslexia, a learning disability that interferes with one's learning process. Adhyayan - a coaching centre that specializes in teaching students with learning disabilities, came to her rescue. Using audio visual techniques, flash cards and other methods, Anandini was slowly guided towards excellence. Anandini, who now wants to major in Psychology, had lost her confidence when she was losing out on her grades in school due to her illness and learning complications. "She sailed through all obstacles and came out a winner," says her mother, her voice beaming with pride. Though her school, Convent of Jesus and Mary, was very supportive in nurturing her and catering to her special needs, "the absence of special schools in the city to attend to kids with special needs, is disturbing", says Rajeev Bhatt, her educator at Adhyayan. To all the parents of students who have received their board results today, Anandini's mother has a message, "Always have faith in your children and don't make marks the ultimate criterion for judging your child's worth."
News.Heading: AI Delhi-San Francisco-Delhi flight to go around the world from next month
News.text: New Delhi: From next month Air India aircraft flying on the Delhi-San Francisco (SFO)-Delhi route will circumnavigate the earth as it will go round the world in less than 36 hours. The Maharaja currently takes the western route while flying Delhi to SFO by crossing the Atlantic, covering a distance of 13,900 km in up to 17 hours. And it flies back home taking the same route in an hour less. From next month, AI plans to fly east to SFO by crossing the vast Pacific Ocean. While this route is almost 1,400 km longer, the Boeing 777-200 (long range or LR) aircraft will get only strong tail winds on its eastward journey and cut flying time by up to three hours. On the return, the plane will fly over the Atlantic. Thus by the time the plane reaches Delhi, it would have gone round the earth is just about a day-and-a-half. The B-777 200 LR, on an average, burns 9,600 litres fuel for each hour of flying. Reducing the flying time to SFO from an hour (in summer) to three hours (in winter) will mean huge fuel saving. The new route, thus, promises to a win-win for all as travellers will reach SFO faster and the airline will burn less fuel. "The earth rotates from west to east and winds also flow in that direction. Flying west means facing strong headwinds (that decreases an aircraft's actual ground speed) and flying east means getting strong tailwinds, which does the opposite. While taking the (western) Atlantic route to SFO, we usually face headwinds of 24 kmph. If our aircraft is doing 800 kmph, its actual ground speed is 776 kmph. Taking the (eastern) Pacific route to SFO will mean getting tailwinds of 138 kmph which will make the aircraft have an actual ground speed of 938 kmph," said a senior AI official. In summer, flying time to SFO over Pacific will be 16 hours an hour less than the Atlantic route. And in winter, the difference will be as high as up to three hours between the two routes, said the official. The airline has sent its Pacific route proposal to the Directorate General of Civil Aviation for clearance as no Indian carrier has flown this route nonstop to the west coast. Jet Airways used to have a Mumbai-Shanghai-SFO connection some years ago. The Atlantic route to SFO sees AI fly over Pakistan, Afghanistan, CIS, Russia, Norway, north Iceland, Greenland; crossing the Atlantic to Canada and then entering the US airspace through Seattle. For the Pacific route, AI has chosen this flight plan: Delhi to Bangladesh, Myanmar, China, South Korea, Japan, crossing the Pacific's vast oceanic airspace and then flying directly to the Golden Gate city. AI avoided Russia on this route due to two issues: lack of adequate alternate airports for landing in an emergency and language problems. "We will mostly return to Delhi taking the Atlantic route. But for some days in a year, we may fly over the Pacific if it leads to some time-saving and translate into less fuel burn," said the official.
News.Heading: Elections in India are a lot like weddings
News.text: The lure of this political spectacle is unmatched as city-based photographer Mahesh Shantaram goes tracking speeches, rallies and the leaders during the recently concluded assembly elections. It started off a chance assignment for an international magazine to cover entrepreneur-turned-politician Nandan Nilekani's political campaign in Bengaluru during the 2014 general elections. Soon, Mahesh Shantaram found himself setting off on "a political backpacking trip" across the country in search of such encounters. After being featured in Tasveer Journal for his photo project 'The Last Days of Manmohan' and entering the British Journal of Photography's list of professionals to watch out for, the 38-year-old photographer hit the campaign trail again to scout for images in Tamil Nadu and Assam last month. To him, the 2014 election was a turning point in many ways. "Since then, I have continued the project by seeking out assembly elections," says Shantaram, who plans to shoot this 'political spectacle' till 2019 and turn it all into a book. And like exit poll pundits, Shantaram is also gobsmacked by Jayalalithaa's comeback. Where all has this journey to photograph the 'tamasha' of politics taken you this year? People get too carried away by the politics of the day . I travel to see politicians perform. I'm interested in the theatre of politics and the visual spectacle that it offers; it is a lens through which to view India itself.This year, I managed to catch the action in Assam and Tamil Nadu. I was struck by the openness and easy-going culture in Assam that was in contrast to the politics of secrecy and suspicion in Tamil Nadu. In Assam, I contacted one MLA (a former home minister) seeking his fifth consecutive term in the assembly on Facebook. When I told him about my project, he immediately invited me to join him on a tour of his constituency right in the middle of a busy election. In Tamil Nadu, a state famously prone to sycophancy and infantile politicians, it wasn't as easy. For instance, to get in touch with Kanimozhi (MP and daughter of DMK leader M Karunanidhi), I contacted many people. When I eventually met Kanimozhi's campaign manager, he was hesitant until I mentioned that I knew Gaurav Gogoi (Congress member and former Assam CM Tarun Gogoi's son). While I got to shoot Kanimozhi, I didn't get to interact with her. As an outsider, do you manage to take photos that may be overlooked by a photojournalist? What is the story you want to tell? On the contrary , it is professional journalists who are outsiders.They are too eager to get a staid picture that merely skims the surface. Such pictures rarely stand the test of time. I stay clear of large election rallies because these are designed to create distance between politicians and people. I try to become an insider as far as possible and get within smelling distance of the action. Aam Aadmi Party launches campaign in Varanasi in 2014. Photo credit: Mahesh Shantaram Was it easy to gain access to politicians? What have been the unconventional ways you have tried to reach out to them? I do whatever it takes- by hook or by crook, and sometimes, going by the book. To catch a politician, you must become the politician. For most of us, TV is the medium through which we see politicians campaigning. I have not had a television since 1994. To satisfy my curiosity , I had to jump right into the ring. When you get closer, you will find that they too have their vulnerable sides, very unlike the glorified figures that we are accustomed to seeing. Beyond the glaze of celebrity spotting, I'm looking for vestiges of politics - - power, hope, frenzy , decadence, decay. What makes India's elections grand spectacles? Politics in the West has become very clinical and sophisticated.Take the current US election campaign for instance. Can you remember any memorable photo? No, because politicians there look like people in business suits attending a corporate conference. Elections in India, on the other hand, are like weddings where you have the politician attending a rally accompanied by his baraat. The reason is that too many people in the country are apathetic and so, in order to get the message across, you need to make a spectacle of it. This is why wherever you go, you will see singing and dancing. In these times of Election Commission Raj, politics is becoming safer and predictable. As a citizen I am grateful. But from the point of view of a photographer, it is terrible! What have been some of the most interesting, unbelievable experiences you have had during the course of this project? I think Pandit Malaviya's (freedom fighter and Congress leader Madan Mohan Malaviya) statue in Varanasi is a ground zero of sorts for several Indian politicians. Many national parties launch their campaign from his statue that is at the entrance of BHU (he founded Banaras Hindu University). I was witness to the legendary Modi vs Kejriwal contest there in 2014. It was an incredible thrill that felt like a special time in a special place. Why have you kept it a self-funded and solo project? The first picture I made as part of this series was during Nilekani's 2014 campaign. At that time, I was on assignment for the Financial Times (UK). It was my first attempt in the political arena. I was so pleased by what I got that I decided to go solo. The simple answer to why I keep it self-funded is independence. What you want to do with the photos you have taken? Is it going to be an ongoing project? A photo project reaches its conclusion when it becomes a book. That happens when the narrative can no longer be improved by adding or removing pictures. To reach that state, I need to shoot for many more years; at least until 2019 to complete a whole cycle of elections.
News.Heading: With 90s up and up, cutoffs set to soar
News.text: NEW DELHI: The Delhi University cutoffs are likely to be quite high this year because of the significant increase in the number of high scorers in the CBSE's Class XII examinations. About 10.8% of the successful candidates--89,030--scored an aggregate of 90% and above while there are 14,838 candidates with more than 95%, a new high. Not everyone is going to line up at DU and also CBSE is yet to give out the number of high scorers from the Delhi region. But consider the fact that DU's total annual intake at the undergraduate level is 54,000. Some college principals believe that though the cutoffs in the first list will remain high, there will be scope for students with a comparatively lower score, especially in sciences, as the number of choices among institutions has increased significantly. In 2010 the number of candidates with an aggregate of 90% and above was 16,563 and with 95% and above, 1,202. Six years on, the number of candidates scoring an aggregate of 90% and above (best five subjects with one language compulsory) has gone up by five times and those scoring 95% and above over 12 times.Just a year ago, the number of candidates scoring 90% and above was 60,000 plus and 95% and above, 12,000. The principal of Deen Dayal Upadhyaya College, S K Garg, observed wryly that the cutoffs are no longer decided by DU but by CBSE. "The purpose of any board examination is to grade the candidates into various categories. If the highest category has 14,000 plus students, then how is it possible to segregate them into various sub-categories? It amounts to almost 1,000 candidates on each mark. It is a mockey of the evaluation system," he said. Another principal of a South Campus college said cutoffs could see an "unprecendented rise" as even the other board results have shown a similar trend. But there are those who feel that since DU is not the first choice of many "top scorers", the situation is not as bad as it is being made out to be. "It is difficult to predict the cutoffs right now. We will have to wait and analyse the pre-admission forms. And in any case, the first cutoff will remain high as we play it safe," said Pratibha Jolly , principal of Miranda House. "Not everybody wants to come to DU and choices of institutions have increased in this country ," she pointed out. "Many science students will prefer IISER (Indian Institute of Science Education and Research) or even NISER (National Institute of Science Education and Research).And high-scoring students will be selective in their choice of courses and institutions. There is a paradigm shift; not everyone wants to come and do BSc or BA. Students are discerning and making smart choices and they are not hesitant in exploring professional courses," she added.
News.Heading: Boxer Vijender Singh reaches early for 'Sarbjit's' Delhi screening
News.text: Boxer Vijender Singh is a fan of Aishwarya Rai Bachchan and was one of the first guests to arrive at the screening of her latest film, 'Sarbjit' , in Delhi on Friday. He told us he'd been looking forward to the film. "I came a bit early and Aishwarya is yet to arrive, but this is one film which I have been waiting to watch," he said. Aishwarya did arrive soon after, and though she didn't stay for the entire film, she had a message for the guests. She said, "This is an important story which, we believe, needs to be told. We pray that what Dalbirji, Sarabjit, Sukhpreet, Swapan and Poonam experienced in their lives does not happen to anybody ever. It would be wrong to say enjoy the screening, but do experience our piece of cinema." Randeep Hooda's family turned up for the screening, so did director Omung Kumar's. Producers Bhushan Kumar and Jackky Bhagnani were also in attendance. Richa Chadha could not attend as she was busy shooting.
News.Heading: African lynched in Delhi after spat over auto ride
News.text: NEW DELHI: A 29-year-old teacher from Congo was bludgeoned to death by three men in south Delhi on Friday after an argument over boarding an auto-rickshaw. The incident was captured on CCTV cameras on Asaf Ali Road near Kishangarh crossing, leading police to prime accused Mobin Azad Saifi, a history-sheeter.Saifi was arrested on Saturday and police are probing the possibility of the lynching being a racial attack. The external affairs ministry has sought a report from Delhi Police. Masunda Ketada Olivier and his friend Samuel had gone to meet another friend in Kishangarh on Friday night to borrow money for Olivier's birthday celebrations. He would have turned 30 on Saturday. On their way back, Olivier flagged an auto which stopped a few metres from him. Three men standing nearby boarded it.When Olivier objected, the men abused him. As Olivier retorted, they got off the auto and began thrashing him. The three men pushed Olivier to the ground and kicked him in the face and abdomen. One of the men then picked up a large stone from the roadside and hit Olivier on the head. Seeing Olivier bleed, a passer-by stopped to save him from the attackers but he too was beaten up. Olivier had sent Samuel to buy cigarettes while he looked for an auto-rickshaw. By the time Samuel returned, the attackers managed to flee. "The men threatened me with dire consequences if I tried to stop them and fled into a lane leading to Kishangarh village. I tried to treat Olivier, but his head was badly smashed and he was bleeding profusely . We sought help from passers-by but no one came to our rescue. He was lying on the road for 20 minutes before the PCR arrived," said Samuel. Olivier was rushed to a lo cal private hospital from where he was referred to the AIIMS Trauma Centre. He died on way to the centre. A team from the Vasant Kunj (north) police station reached the scene and recovered CCTV footage from the area. Olivier's mobile phone and the stone used to smash his head were recovered from the spot. DCP south Ishwar Singh said CCTV footage showed Saifi along with his accom plices Prakash Musa and Mukesh walking away from the scene. Police said Saifi was involved in a brawl in 2015 and was jailed for three months. He had met Mukesh and Prakash in jail and the trio had planned to commit crimes together. A case of murder has been registered and a manhunt is on for Musa and Mukesh. Olivier's family is set to reach Delhi on Monday . Samuel said Olivier had come to the city in 2011 to pursue a master's degree in foreign languages from Delhi University . He had lately started teaching French at his rented apartment in South Extension. He had come to India on a student visa and was to go back soon. Samuel said Olivier's parents had to sell a plot to send him to India. "We respect Indians... but they beat him up like an animal and tried to rob his belongings. They fled as Samuel reached the spot," said Jonathan, Olivier's friend.
News.Heading: Comedians write open letters to the CBSE topper
News.text: Don't make it sound easy and simple! If you can't help the ones who didn't score well, then at least don't hurt them! You scored a 100 in physics. Who does that?! It's not human! Nishant Joke Singh To the girl who scored 497 marks out of 500 in her board exams and made life difficult for others, Sukriti Gupta, You don't know me, but everyone knows you. Congratulations. What you have achieved is spectacular. Your family must be very proud of you. You must be receiving phone calls and messages from everyone to congratulate you for your success. You'll be addressed as 'the CBSE topper' for a long time. It'll be your new identity, and rightly deserved so. You'll be on every news channel and in every newspaper. There will be blogs written about you. However, as I write this piece, I also feel a lot of people being jealous of your achievement. I am one of them. I am 32 years old, but I still remember my Board exam results. I scored less than half of what you have. Thank God you didn't study in my school. Thank God you didn't live in my neighbourhood. However, everyone is not as lucky as me. Have you, for once, thought about the other kids who haven't scored like you in exams? There are kids who play or party or just hang out with friends throughout the year. There are kids who find it boring to complete their assignments. There are kids who are like me. Yesterday, my mom again reminded me of my Board results. She said, "Your life could have been so much better had you concentrated on studies instead of wasting your time. You could have been a doctor, a pilot or an engineer, instead of being a stand-up comedian." It doesn't matter to her that many doctors, engineers and pilots have paid me to tell them jokes and make them laugh. Such is life. You have scored 100 in Physics and Chemistry, and 99 in English, Math and Computer Science. Who does that?! That's not human! I speak, on behalf of all those people, whose scores are not like yours - next time, when you decide to answer all those questions, just think about others who don't know all the answers. As the Dalai Lama XIV once said, "Our prime purpose in this life is to help others. And if you can't help them, at least don't hurt them." And everyone else who is reading this letter and hasn't scored well in their board exams, what are you waiting for? Start writing jokes RIGHT NOW. - Nishant Joke Singh READ ALSO Never stressed myself, says CBSE toper Sukriti Tell people it is impossible without divine intervention! Amit Tondon Dear Sukriti, In the next few weeks, quite a few newborns will be named Sukriti, Indian quiz books will add your name to the next edition and your relatives will grow tenfold. Of course, congratulations are in order, but I just have one request - when you talk to press, don't talk as if it was simple and easy. Why did you do this? Sorry, but firstly you score unbelievable marks, and then talk about it as if it is not even that tough! Even when they interview Sachin Tendulkar after a century, he talks about a strategy and gives you an analysis. By the end of it, we understand that this wasn't something that we could have done. So in the case of Sachin, no parents ask their kid "Agar Sachin kar sakta hai toh tu kyun nahin?" My request on behalf of all mediocre students is that at least in your interviews, talk as if you have a God-given talent, or it involved a five-year-long daily ritual by the parents (so that other parents can be equally blamed for the non-performance of their kids). For the next five years, every parent-child conversation among your acquaintances will have the phrase "Sukriti ko dekh..." So if your younger cousins look at you with contempt or friends hug you a little lighter, please understand the emotion. A lot of hopeful parents will bring their kids to you and say, "Beta, isko bhi samhja de thoda." If you have a younger sibling, don't expect too much from him/her in the next few days. If I was your younger sibling, I would advise you to not even drink water served by me. Finally, this is a great opportunity to get all your wishes fulfilled from your parents! Nothing makes an Indian parent happier than a kid who is all over newspapers and is also a topper. So their chequebook belongs to you! From a world tour to a new car or allowing a Facebook account, they will get you anything! Speaking of Facebook, my parting advice would be to STAY AWAY from it right now. Everyone and their cousins are writing about how marks don't matter at all in the long term. This includes celebs as well. So, it will be a bit depressing browsing a world that is screaming that your achieve ment means nothing. So, avoid social media, make a wish list and hand it over to your proud parents. And keep in mind your social responsibility towards the lesser students. Tell people it is almost impossible without divine intervention! - Amit Tandon You'll waltz into the college your choice, but once you get in, you'll have to learn to live in the limelight Papa CJ Dear Sukriti, I got 76% in my Board exam, and failed to get admission into a college and course of my choice. And when I go to work, people laugh at me! And when they do that, it is considered a good result! So heed my counsel in that context, and if it sounds particularly stupid, making it sound sensible was probably in that 24% of the syllabus that I wasn't able to master. One of the best pieces of advice I ever got was that it is important for you to 'grow in the dark'. Once you hit the limelight, you don't have the freedom to mess up. Due to the pressure, you get scared to experiment, and that inhibits your growth. Unbeknownst to you, you have just become a celebrity. You will realise that the first day you step into college, if you haven't already. Sukriti, you will face challenges that others will not. The problem with getting to the very top is that staying there is very hard and often, there is only one direction you can go if you don't stay there. You'll waltz into the college and course of your choice, but once you get in, you'll have to learn to live in the limelight. If you will allow a 76 percenter to share some counsel, let me say this - celebrity is a currency. You can decide how you choose to spend it. While you may never be asked about your marks again, the quality of your relationships will have far greater bearing on the quality of your life than this outstanding academic achievement. I'd like to end by quoting Sukriti Gupta , Class 12 CBSE topper 2016 - "You need to get your basics right, and then the rest is not that hard to crack. I have been consistent throughout and that helped me." Follow her example, and with luck, life will be as kind to you as the examiners were! Congratulations and all the very best! -Papa CJ READ ALSO Sukriti Gupta tops CBSE Class 12 exams You don't need luck because you already have the skill Radhika Vaz Dear Sukriti, Congratulations! Ok look, you have no idea who I am, so I hope you won't be too weirded out by this open letter. Or let's just call it fan mail because that is what this is. You have fans now because you are famous. Which, in your case, is good, because you are famous for being smart and hardworking - two things I am but very rarely at the same time. And that is why I admire people who excel - whether it's you or Usain Bolt. It takes two things to be a baller - talent and discipline. Of course, the talent part is easy, it's the daily grind that's the hard part. And to see someone so young have the maturity to recognise that is thrilling. Sukriti, what you have done is praiseworthy. Because you have done is not because of our educational system or because of the support our country gives young women, but despite it. The fact that your family has supported you, and pushed you to become a role model at such a young age, is truly incredible. I hope you will always be the feminist you are - leading the way for the rest of us, showing us that women can, and they will not be left behind. You don't need luck because you already have the skill, so I will sign off with my love. Yeah, I think I just made that creepy, but there you go... -Radhika Vaz
News.Heading: Time to fix power firms: Arvind Kejriwal
News.text: NEW DELHI: Even as Delhiites are suffering from regular power cuts in this sweltering heat, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal said on Saturday said that his government was personally attending to every complaint it received. He said that a policy will also be enforced under which compensation would be provided to people suffering from power cuts for more than two hours. Kejriwal said his government would ensure that consumers who face unscheduled outages are compensated. Policy directions have already been issued to the Delhi Electricity Regulatory Commission (DERC), which will come out with a notification soon. "In Delhi, there have been many power cuts lately and for the past few days I have been monitoring the situation. In the BSES areas, the power cuts are more than usual. In comparison, in areas under Tata Power Delhi Distribution Limited, the cuts are fewer. On Friday, the power minister took cognizance of the matter and we are personally observing all the complaints that are coming through," said the CM. Kejriwal said he would not let the power utilities get away with blaming the cuts on local faults. "It's time to take the power companies to task. Every time they come up with an excuse blaming local faults... then they should also assess why these faults are happening. I have been getting a huge number of complaints... in fact I have been attending to complaints of power cuts throughout the night," he said. When told that discoms needed to be dealt with a stick, the CM assured that the government "has a stick to deal with the power companies and there was no shortage of sticks". Stating that he has called a meeting regarding the matter on Monday, Kejriwal added that he has given direction to the DERC that when there is an 'unscheduled' power cut, it has to be fixed within two hours and if it is not done so, then the people in that area will be compensated. The CM's statements were echoed by power minister Satyender Jain, who held a media conference later in the day to address the situation. "There is no shortage of power availability. Power cuts are only on account of local faults and this proves that the power utilities have failed in routine maintenance of their infrastructure. We have issued directions to DERC under Section 108 to penalise the discoms whenever unscheduled power cuts are reported and the notification should be out soon. The compensation amount for those who suffer outages will be reflected in the electricity bills," said the minister. Jain also said that many consumers have complained that discom call centres keep them waiting for upto 20 minutes and even after that their complaints are not resolved. "Call centres have been told that they have to call back each and every consumer who registers a complaint to ensure their problem is resolved. We have also said that these calls should be recorded so we can monitor them," he added. "Two reasons for privatisation was investment into the sector and its maintenance. And it's pretty obvious that the discoms have not invested enough in maintenance of the infrastructure," the minister said.
News.Heading: Message of introspection amid grand swearing-in plan for Mamata
News.text: Kolkata: Chief minister Mamata Banerjee woke up early on Friday morning as a crowd was impatiently waiting in front of 30B Harish Chatterjee Street to take a glimpse of their favourite leader. She came out of her home at 8.30am and received flower bouquets from visitors who had come from various parts of the city. Didi shook hands with some of them and later handed over packets of sweets to the children. Mamata's residence on Friday turned into a centre of celebration with VIPs, administrators, event managers, journalists and visitors making a beeline to meet her either to chalk out future plans or enquire about the grand swearing-in ceremony to be held on May 27. Banerjee had convened a meeting of the newly-elected MLAs. But before anybody from her team of 210 MLAs could reach her house, Banerjee reportedly held a closed-door meeting with her trusted lieutenants Subrata Bakshi and Mukul Roy. "The names of probable ministers in the next cabinet were discussed in the meeting," said a source. The meeting with the MLAs started with a loud applause for Didi for the historic victory of the party despite threat from alliance. The meeting ended with a note of caution - introspection in the rank and file of the party following failures in some key assembly constituencies, including Jadavpur. The newly-elected MLAs were offered fish fry, fried rice, chicken and sweets. However, Mamata opted for a light lunch - rice and 'kalmi saag' with chilly. After spending a while in her room speaking to family members, she went back to her lucky office room where she held a series of meetings till the evening. The IAS association members led by chief secretary Basudev Bandopadhyay met her. An IPS delegation was in the queue. Mamata called them in and passed on necessary instruction especially in the wake of escalating political tensions. Mamata, however, did not forget to discuss about the swearing-in ceremony which will be held on Red Road. "This function is very close to Didi's heart. This time she has chosen Red Road to make sure that even common people can become a part of it. We have been flooded with requests for passes from the people of her locality. We will also take our family members there," said Karthick Banerjee, Mamata's brother. In fact, she has asked senior Trinamool Congress leaders to form a committee that will look after the preparations for the swearing-in ceremony. "I will be happy if people in large numbers take part in the ceremony," Mamata said.
News.Heading: 3 climbers from Kolkata 'missing' on Everest, 4 summit
News.text: KOLKATA: Four climbers from Kolkata summitted Mt Everest on Saturday morning, but the cheer was dampened by reports that three other climbers may be missing in what's known as the `Death Zone' -8000m and above. The grim news comes just a day after news reached that Everester Rajib Bhattacharya was killed on the descent from Mt Dhaulagiri, the seventh highest peak. While Ramesh Roy, Malay Mukherjee, Satyarup Siddhanta and Rudraprasad Haldar stood on top of the world at 5.40am and were back in Camp IV by Saturday evening, there has been no contact with climbers Sunita Hazra, Gautam Ghosh and Paresh Nath since Friday evening. They were last tracked at 7.30pm on Friday when they started their climb for the summit. "We have not heard anything about them since then," said Sudeb Hazra, Sunita's husband. Both groups were with different agencies. The four that are confirmed safe were with 7-Summit agency. Its owner Mingma Sherpa confirmed that they reached Camp IV at 7.50pm. Those yet to be traced are with Loben Expedition, which has an office in Darjeeling. Curiously, the family of a Loben climber, Subhas Pal, were told that he was seen around 11.30am on Saturday climbing down to Camp IV along with the four from 7-Summit. For the friends and family of Ramesh, Malay, Satyarup and Rudraprasad, it's a day of celebration. Satyarup's friend Tirthankar Pyne told TOI how he was tracking him via a GPS gadget he had strapped on."At 5.40am, it flashed on my laptop screen -8,848 meters! I knew it was emitting from Satyarup's GPS. My friends and I were glued to GPS tracking websites all night, checking every movement of the four-member team," he said. The last update on Satyarup's Facebook page was at 6.30pm on Friday: "With all ur blessings starting for the final push. Keep us in ur prayers." The phrase "final push" told his friends that they were striking out for the summit. They had arrived at South Col at 1.30pm and rested a while before going for the peak. Beyond Camp IV , the final outpost between Everest and Lhotse at an altitude of around 26,000 feet or 8,000 meters, is what mountaineers call the Death Zone. Here, a climber's body stops acclamatising and starts dying slowly till the climber returns to below 8,000m. Till Camp IV , all eight climbers from Kolkata were in good health. On Lhotse face, a Sherpa met with an accident and died while opening the route, say sources. There were also issues with the oxygen in stock but it was sorted out. "They had chosen this time of the year as the weather forecast was good. They expected it to be less windy ," said Tirthankar.Things didn't go according to plan, though. On May 5, the weather was fluctuating at Camp II. Till Camp IV , the climbers had to retuern to the previous camps for better acclamatisation. Till May 7, they had only touched 7,100m. More challenges came when the team's oxygen was used by another team. But the four made it to the top. "It was Ramesh's second try . Last year, they reached base camp the day Nepal suffered a devastating earthquake. They had to come back and the entire investment was a loss. It was hard arranging funds this year," said Tirthankar. Ramesh, a Central Excise inspector, is a veteran climber. While Satyarup has conquered six of the seven top summits, Malay has scaled Kamet summit -the second highest mountain in the Garhwal region. On May 19, Satyarup posted on Facebook: "Our summit day so far is 21st early morning." They had chosen to scale the summit during sundown as days are even deadlier with chances of molten ice causing fatalities. Kolkata is already celebrating the success of Pradeep and and his wife Chetna Sahoo who reached the summit on Thursday along with teammate Debraj Dutta. It was the couple's third attempt after two failed tries.
News.Heading: When NOTA becomes the deciding factor
News.text: Kolkata: CPM's Sujit Chakraborty won from Barjora in Bankura defeating actor Sohom Chakrabarty by a margin of only 616 votes. Deboshree Roy defeated CPM veteran Kanti Ganguly from Raidighi in South 24-Parganas by 1229 votes. They couldn't have made it without the NOTA (None of the Above) votes that in a way became the deciding factor in these constituencies. Here, NOTA votes were higher than the victory margin. In Barjora, the votes polled in favour of NOTA was 4235, and in case of Raidighi it was 1710. NOTA votes are higher than the victory margin in as many as 21 constituencies. If this is a trend, it displays the underlying facts over vote transfers. "There has been an alliance between our party and the Left. The top leaders have decided it. But how could I cast my vote for a party that has been our enemy since years? Rather, I decided to cast my vote in favour of NOTA," an assistant secretary of Congress told TOI on condition of anonymity. If this gave advantage to Trinamool, there are instances where faction feuds within Trinamool triggered a rise in NOTA votes. Among these 21 constituencies, six went to Left and four with Congress. Chhatna in Bankura recorded the highest NOTA polling - 7709 - where RSP candidate Dhirendranath Layel defeated Trinamool candidate Subhashis Batabyal by a margin of 2417 votes. Take the example of Kalchini where Trinamool candidate Wilson Champamari won by a margin of 1511 when the number of NOTA votes was 4524. Indranil Sen of the ruling party won from Chandernagore by a margin of only 2114 votes when the NOTA figure was as high as 3853. This is also true in case of Tamluk where Nirbed Roy lost to Ashok Dinda of CPM by a margin of 520 votes. But, 2394 NOTA votes were polled here. Records show a total of 8.30 lakh people in Bengal opted for NOTA. This is more than the four other states - Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Assam and Puducherry - that went to the polls this year. When asked about it, Psephologist Biswanath Chakraborty said, "There are people from both Congress and Left who couldn't give their votes to the parties they considered to be their main rival for so many years. This resulted in the rise in the NOTA percentage. Since NOTA is a relatively new thing, people were not aware of it in the last two elections. I believe that with time this number will increase. The young generation who are politically disillusioned and didn't want to waste their votes chose NOTA as the best alternative."
News.Heading: Coimbatore celebrates Jaya win with big bang
News.text: Coimbatore: With exit polls in their favour, the DMK was expecting to win by a huge margin. As the day dawned, the DMK office in the city was vibrant with activity. As they were debating on what margin they would win, they got a harsh reality check from news channels which began announcing that the AIADMK was in the lead. Soon the mood became sombre, with party workers making frantic calls to their functionaries stationed at the counting centres, to confirm what they were hearing. However, even at this point, the DMK did not lose hope. As the day progressed, it was difficult to keep hope alive, especially when Modi tweeted at 11am to congratulate Jayalalithaa on her victory. On the other hand, the day started on a quiet note for AIADMK cadres with very few people in the party office. Most candidates were at the counting centre discussing the progress. As their leads increased gradually, they became more relaxed and returned to the office. Waiting for the final results, the cadres slowly began gathering at the party office located at Anna Salai at 3pm. The mood was still very restrained with occasional claps and whistles when remarks on AIADMK victory was were made. Only when Jayalalithaa spoke to her party men through television, did the crowds begin to celebrate with abandon. The BJP camp was much more relaxed where candidates could be seen sipping a cup of coffee and munching on snacks. While in all other party offices, cadres were glued to the television, cadres in the BJP office were in front of the computer analysing the results round wise and also trying to analyse the outcome. Also, this was the only party office, where the candidates was present. Even as the candidates expressed their concern over the results, the cadres tried to lift the mood by saying they should wait for final results to be announced. In the evening, when AIADMK won nine of the ten constituencies, the victorious candidates received their certificates at the counting centre while cadres distributed sweets and burst crackers. The DMK party office, on the other hand was silent and there was a wave of disappointment in the air. Unable to understand the reason, the cadres said money power of the ruling party had worked against them.
News.Heading: BJP workers protest outside CPM office, 600 detained
News.text: NEW DELHI: BJP workers on Sunday staged a demonstration outside the CPM headquarters here, broke police barriers and damaged their signboard in protest against the murder of a party worker allegedly by supporters of the Left party during a poll victory rally in Kerala. BJP has been targeting the Left over the alleged attacks on its workers in Kerala in the run up to the polls. Several police teams were deployed and a four-tier security arrangement was made around the CPM office in New Delhi's Gole Market area this morning. CPM workers had also come out of the building to confront the protesters and a minor scuffle broke out when a group of BJP workers broke police barriers and damaged the signboard at the CPM headquarters. The groups were separated by the police and no injuries were reported, police maintained. "Around 600 people have been detained under provisions of law and the situation is under control," DCP (New Delhi) Jatin Narwal said. Holding that the protest was peaceful, Delhi BJP spokesman Praveen Kapoor said, "Police detained our leaders and workers but not the CPM workers who resorted to violence. Hundreds of party workers, including Delhi in-charge Shyam Jaju and president (Satish Upadhyay) have been detained." CPM leader Prakash Karat said, "No one was injured in the attack. But the police personnel deployed there did not prevent them from coming up to the office." A police complaint has been lodged in connection with the incident, a CPM worker said. On Thursday, BJP worker Pramod (38) had sustained head injuries after he was allegedly hit by a brick following a clash during a victory rally by CPM workers at Idavilangu in Kerala. He died the next day. BJP chief Amit Shah had yesterday accused the Left Front of "violating" the people's mandate. BJP had said it will not sit quiet if the "cycle of violence" continues in the state as it claimed that it has emerged as a powerful alternative voice to the two main fronts led by CPM and Congress. Kapoor said, "The protest is against the violence in Kerala and the killing of our party worker there." The protesters started marching in groups from the Delhi BJP office in Pandit Pant Marg and gathered outside the outer-most barricading near the Left party's office.
